> [bot](#comment_158_1KdnTJVBGzEZrJppFZtzfG9chukuMv8xSb): My study has mostly been in the node.js direction. Within Electron we can cross-feed data wherever there is a security roadblock in default Zeronet. The discussion and announcement of removing ajax and other techniques of reading or writing data made my decision to fork as best i could. 

You use a fork of zeronet to do Fuzium, which is based on Electron framework, which is based on chromium, which is based on Google Chrome?

While I LOVE the idea and implementation of Electron and the feeling of Web-based standalone apps in general (like firefox prism before), I am not sure if using anything Chromium-based for something as privacy-critical as zeronet is longterm good idea, because of too many unkown variables in the underlying monstercode and despite it being opensource (much like android):
https://github.com/Eloston/ungoogled-chromium/tree/master

I googled for something equivalent from mozilla, but it oddly seems their only counterproject (called Positron) has been discontinued a few days ago, which seems odd with Mozillas prime goal wanting to be at the front of webdevelopment.

Nevertheless please continue your work on Fuzium, maybe some people here or elsewhere figure things out because of importance with more and more people using electron as a base.
